metadata.case_name: Lala Ram Swaruup & Ors. v. Shikar Chand & Anr.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1, Lala Ram Swaruup, and five other members of his family sued the two respondents, Shikar Chand and his son, for ejectment from the shop situated in Qasba Chandausi, Bazar Waram.
The said premises had been let out to the respondents to conduct their shop on a monthly rent with effect from the 11th April, 1952, for a year.
Appellants pleaded that they needed the premises in suit to carry on their own business in the shop.

Appellants applied for permission to the District Magistrate, Moradabad, under S. 3(1) of the U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947; permission refused; moved Commissioner in revision under S. 3(2); Commissioner granted permission to file the suit.
Suit No. 349 of 1954 filed on 14th July, 1954; claimed ejectment and damages for use and occupation from 11th April, 1953 to 11th July, 1954 at Rs. 35/- per month.
Respondents resisted on grounds: suit bad for non-joinder of necessary parties; permission by Commissioner invalid; rent note inadmissible; notice under s.106 TP Act invalid.
Learned Munsif, Chandausi, decreed suit with costs on 25th March, 1955.
Respondents' appeal (Civil Appeal No. 213 of 1955) dismissed by District Judge, Moradabad, on 2nd June, 1955.
High Court single Judge allowed second appeal No. 1106 of 1955 on 26th July, 1956, holding permission invalid.
Letters Patent Appeal No. 212 of 1956: majority (two judges) held permission invalid, dismissed appeal on 13th September, 1960.
Appellants obtained certificate from High Court for appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether courts below had jurisdiction to consider the validity of the permission granted by the Commissioner under s.3 of the Act.
Whether the permission granted by the Commissioner was without jurisdiction and a nullity.

petitioner_arguments.text: Courts below had no jurisdiction to consider validity of permission; s.3 of the Act provides self-contained code; decisions of authorities final under s.3(4) and s.16.
Commissioner's jurisdiction under s.3(3) is wide, not limited like s.115 CPC; covers illegality, material irregularity, or wrongly refusing to act.

respondent_arguments.text: Permission granted by Commissioner invalid in law.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: U.P. Act III of 1947, s.3(3) akin to CPC s.115

court_reasoning.text: Jurisdiction of civil courts excluded by s.3(4) and s.16 except where plea goes to root and renders order nullity (e.g., lack of authority, jurisdictional error, violation of natural justice).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bar does not apply to pleas proving nullity.

court_reasoning.text: Respondents' plea does not render permission nullity; Commissioner's power under s.3(3) wide: acted illegally, with material irregularity, or wrongly refused to act; not limited to jurisdictional errors like s.115 CPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.3(3) unambiguous, covers merits; amendment confirms wide intent.

court_reasoning.text: Proceedings under s.3 quasi-judicial, must follow natural justice; violation would make nullity.

holdings.text: Civil courts' jurisdiction excluded under ss.3(4),16 except for nullity pleas.
Permission by Commissioner valid; not nullity as s.3(3) confers wide revisional powers.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lala Shri Bhagwan v. Shri Ram Chand
precedents_cited.relevance: Proceedings under s.3 quasi-judicial; must follow natural justice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Secretary of State for India v. Roy Jatindra Nath Chowdhury
precedents_cited.relevance: Finality subject to fundamental irregularity or non-compliance with procedure essentials.

precedents_cited.case_name: Secretary of State v. Mask & Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Civil courts can examine non-compliance with Act or violation of natural justice despite exclusion.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ms Kamala Mills Ltd. v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Supports civil courts examining nullity despite exclusion.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raleigh Investment Company Ltd v. Governor General in Council
precedents_cited.relevance: Civil courts jurisdiction where statutory tribunal acts without conformity to judicial procedure.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs permission for ejectment suits; excludes civil court jurisdiction except nullity; Commissioner's wide revisional powers.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: Notice of termination challenged by respondents.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Respondents analogized Commissioner's power to High Court's revisional jurisdiction; court distinguished.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, holding that civil courts lack jurisdiction to question the Commissioner's permission except on nullity grounds, and the permission was valid under the wide powers of s.3(3); reversed High Court decision.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; suit decreed in favor of appellants.

key_quotes.text: "the jurisdiction of the civil courts is excluded in relation to matters covered by the orders included within the provisions of s.3(4) and s.16."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on exclusion of jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: "the bar created by the relevant provisions of the Act excluding the jurisdiction of the civil courts cannot operate in cases where the plea raised before the civil court goes to the root of the matter and would, if upheld, lead to the conclusion that the impugned order is a nullity."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Exception to jurisdiction bar for nullity pleas.

key_quotes.text: "the words used in S.3(3) are unambiguous. There are three categories of cases in which the Commissioner can interfere with the order passed by the District Magistrate."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines wide scope of Commissioner's powers.
